case_vignette: A 62-year-old man presents to your office for evaluation of a chronic ulcer on the plantar aspect of his right foot. He has a history of peripheral vascular disease and poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus. He states that he has had this ulcer for years, but that it seems to be growing. On examination of his right foot you note the heaped up edges surrounding the ulcer (Figure A). A wedge biopsy reveals irregular masses of anaplastic epidermal cells proliferating down to the dermis and the pathologist reports "keratin pearls".
question: What is the diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've got this sore on the bottom of my right foot that's been there for years and seems to be getting bigger.
How old are you?
I am 62 years old.
Have you been diagnosed with any chronic medical conditions?
Yes, I have peripheral vascular disease and poorly-controlled diabetes.
Are you currently taking any medications for your conditions? If so, could you please list them?
I'm sorry, I don't have that information.
Do you have any family history of skin conditions or diabetes?
I'm not sure, I don't have that information.
**Final Diagnosis:** Diabetic Foot Ulcer
